docs.lead_paragraph: PRESIDENT Bush went to Wall Street on a mission last week. He wanted to reassure a skittish financial community worried that cascading stories of malfeasance by big business will further undermine public confidence. Mr. Bush recently talked of looking for inspiration in another president who led the nation in an era of corporate wrongdoing: Theodore Roosevelt. But Mr. Bush might not realize that Roosevelt was far more radical than any Republican of today. In fact, Roosevelt advocated a restructuring of government-business relations more radical than most Democrats now seek. While President Bush has proposed relatively minor reforms -- like hiring additional S.E.C. regulators -- these look tame when compared to Roosevelt's calls for a fundamental government intervention in the economy. He wanted national incorporation to make sure no corporation stayed in business if it violated the law repeatedly. He called for strict regulation of the stock market and a stronger Federal Trade Commission. He said he would like nothing better than to force companies to open their books to federal investigators and to make executives personally liable for jail when their corporations broke the law. The government should act like a referee, throwing cheaters out of the game to ensure fair play.

headline.main: The Nation; For T.R., Government Was the Solution

docs.abstract: Kathleen Dalton article contrasts ex-Pres Theodore Roosevelt's battle for government regulation to battle corporate malfeasance with Pres Bush's free-market-age sensibilities; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Body-conscious diners who stock their handbags with appetite-suppressing tea bags and salad dressings may want to make room for the latest. Now there's the pre-dinner mint, pills to aid digestion by We Care, the holistic health spa in Palm Springs, Calif., where many celebrities flock for juice fasting, to load up on enzymes, and to get daily colonics. The spa's carryout line ($13 to $30 at www.wecarespa.com or 800-888-2523) includes digestive enzymes, acidophilus, energy pills with kyo green and power green, and fiber regulators, all of which are said to promote digestion, purify the blood, detoxify the liver and replenish the intestines with beneficial bacteria. ''The pills are selling like hot cakes,'' said Susy Lombardi, the owner of the spa. In New York, similar digestive aids can be found at Whole Foods in Chelsea (250 Seventh Avenue). Consider it a little insurance for fitting into those low-rise Seven jeans. KAREN ROBINOVITZ
docs.abstract: We Care health spa in Palm Springs, Calif, is offering digestive enzymes, energy pills and fiber regulators said to promote digestion; photo (Pulse column) (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: JIM DOWNS is a 70-year-old grandfather of 17 who became a Roman Catholic priest last month. At the Holy Apostles Seminary in Cromwell, where he had been studying for the last five years, this is not considered unusual. Founded in 1956, the small seminary near the center of town is one of only three Roman Catholic seminaries in the United States that offers older men an opportunity to study for the priesthood.

headline.main: The View From/Cromwell; Older, Wiser and Seeking a New Walk of Life: the Priesthood

docs.lead_paragraph: L.I. Health Network Drops Empire Blue Cross One of the region's largest health care networks said Monday it would stop accepting reimbursement from Empire Blue Cross Blue Shield following the breakdown of rate increase negotiations after a year. The Long Island Health Network, which represents approximately 3,400 beds, terminated its contract with Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, effective Aug. 11. The move would affect the patients of more than 5,000 doctors.
docs.abstract: Long Island Health Network, in move affecting patients of more than 5,000 doctors, terminates contract with Emire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, effective August 11; insurer had agreed to pay $21.6 million to some 52,000 members of class-action suit charging it improperly handled claims reimbursements and other responsibilities over six-year period (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: UNLESS something remarkable happens over the next six months, 2002 will be the third consecutive year of declines in major United States stock market averages. The last time that happened was 60 years ago. Since the market peak in March 2000, roughly $7 trillion in stock wealth has evaporated, leaving about $10.5 trillion.

headline.main: Waiting For the Green Light On Stocks

docs.lead_paragraph: The Queens borough president has proposed a resolution to the four-weeklong bus strike in Queens. Under the proposal, 1,500 striking drivers, mechanics and cleaners would receive increases in health benefits that would be paid for by savings in the bus companies' budgets. As of late last night, the union representing the drivers said it had not yet studied the proposal and was not ready to declare an end to the strike, according to a union spokesman.

headline.main: New Proposal For Ending Bus Strike In Queens

docs.lead_paragraph: Ten days after it closed, this city's only trauma center is to reopen on Saturday morning under an agreement that temporarily limits the liability of its doctors to malpractice lawsuits. On July 3, most of the surgeons attached to the trauma unit at the University of Nevada Medical Center, about 67 in all, resigned from the practice because of what they said were the high costs of medical liability and malpractice insurance and the lack of caps on jury awards for pain and suffering. The resignations forced the closing of the center, which opened in 1989 and last year treated 11,439 people for injuries incurred in auto accidents, shootings and other life-threatening events.

headline.main: Deal on Liability Allows Trauma Center to Reopen

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A2-6 Signs Hint China's Leader May Be Reluctant to Leave Jiang Zemin, who was expected to give up the presidency in March, is being lionized in a propaganda campaign that is provoking speculation about his ambitions to hold on to power. A1 China is modernizing its military with the goal of countering American power in the Pacific and pressing Taiwan to accept unification, a Pentagon study said. The new study is more hawkish than one made under the Clinton administration in its analysis of China's ambitions and potential threat to the United States. A4

docs.lead_paragraph: Pennsylvania's program to help low-income elderly people buy prescription drugs, the largest in the nation, provides invaluable assistance to tens of thousands of people and is immensely popular, but it also shows the problems that could become endemic if Congress adds drug benefits to Medicare. The program here costs patients only $6 a prescription and rarely denies coverage. It is financed with proceeds from the state lottery. Despite significant use of generic drugs, however, costs have soared and outstripped revenues.

headline.main: Pennsylvania Struggles to Repair Model Prescription Aid Program

docs.abstract: Pennsylvania seeks new sources of revenue as it considers expanding popular prescription drug plan, largest in nation, which aids tens of thousands of low-income elderly people; photo; program costs patients only $6 a perscription, rarely denies coverage and is financed with state lottery proceeds; costs have soared, outstripping revenues despite significant use of generic drugs; problems could worsen if Congress votes to add drug benefits to Medicare (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: By a vote of 16 to 5, a Senate committee approved a bill today that would greatly expand access to low-cost generic versions of prescription drugs. The full Senate plans a free-swinging election year debate on drug prices next week. Even supporters said they were surprised by the lopsided vote on the bill, the first major setback in years for the industry that manufactures brand-name prescription drugs sold in the United States and around the world.

headline.main: Committee Backs Expansion Of Access to Low-Cost Drugs

docs.abstract: Senate committee votes 16 to 5 to greatly expand access to low-cost generic versions of prescription drugs; photo of Sens Tom Harkin and Hillary Clinton; even supporters are surprised by lopsided vote, setback for major drug companies; all Republican supporters are up for re-election this year; bill, likely vehicle for long-awaited floor debate on Medicare coverage, is victory for Sens Charles Schumer and John McCain (M)
